paragraphs.text: Max Factor can't claim credit for Marilyn Monroe.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: Max Factor has appointed Marilyn Monroe as its new "global ambassador", leaving some people bemused at the idea of selecting an ambassador who has been dead since 1962
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They seem to suspect this might limit her diplomatic utility
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But Monroe represents just what Max Factor wants to resuscitate: the glamour for which the company was once a byword
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the era of classic Hollywood (about 1920-1965), Max Factor ran the only cosmetic game in town
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: pioneering the use of makeup for cinema, and then, with his sons, adapting and selling those products commercially
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Monroe remains one of the most iconic Hollywood movie stars
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Max Factor's spokeswoman said they chose her because she epitomises their history
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "Marilyn made the sultry red lip, creamy skin and dramatically lined eyes the most famous beauty look of the 1940s, and it's a look that continues to dominate the beauty and fashion industry. It is the ultimate look that defines glamour - nothing else compares," the spokeswoman said
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The campaign will emphasise Monroe's metamorphosis, it was reported this week, from "mousey" Norma Jeane Mortenson to glamorous Marilyn Monroe, a decision that seems, at face value, rather canny
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Certainly it has stirred up a bit of welcome publicity around the campaign
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which claims in particular that it was Max Factor Jr's idea to bleach the star's naturally chestnut hair to that famous platinum blonde
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The ad campaign reads: "From Norma Jeane to Marilyn Monroe. Created By Max Factor."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Hang on, boys
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: Created by whom?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: If
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Max Factor wants to emphasise history
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: it should start by paying a little more attention to it
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Monroe had her first - tiny - film role in 1947
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: she did not have her first starring role until 1952
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Throughout the 1940s, she was still "mousey" Norma Jeane
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: For my book on Monroe, I read every major biography then published, as well as many ancillary accounts - about 300 books in all
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Not one reported that Max Factor suggested the aspiring starlet should bleach her hair
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: I don't think any of them mentioned Max Factor at all
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Instead
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: nearly all credit a woman named Emmeline Snively, the head of Monroe's first modelling agency, with whom she signed in 1945
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Snively gave Marilyn lessons in fashion, lighting and grooming, and, most biographers report, recommended that she lighten her hair
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "because a blonde could be photographed in any wardrobe and in any light"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: By 1946 the model Norma Jeane had appeared on 33 magazine covers - quite a feat for a "mousey" young woman waiting to be created by Max Factor
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Marilyn Monroe was not created by Max Factor - or by her studio head, Darryl F Zanuck(who hated her); or by her agent, Johnny Hyde, who paid for her to have minor plastic surgery (to the tip of her nose and her jawline) and got her first big roles; or by any of her directors, or husbands, or any other of a legion of men, and a handful of women
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who have tried to claim the credit, now including Max Factor's heirs
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: She was not created by makeup, in any sense
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: cosmetics were not sufficient to create Marilyn Monroe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: neither were other people
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Emmeline Snively herself said that what distinguished the girl she knew was how hard she worked
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: "She wanted to learn, wanted to be somebody, more than anybody I ever saw before in my life."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Everyone from Elton John to Joyce Carol Oates(who should know better) has trotted out this tenacious, tiresome story
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: "ordinary" Norma Jeane was changed by someone else into the glamorous movie star Marilyn Monroe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But Norma Jeane Baker, as she was known in childhood(Mortenson was the name on her birth certificate, but she never knew her father), was always an extremely beautiful girl
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: An army photographer discovered her when she was 19, working at a munitions factory
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: She went on to be a popular model on the cover of dozens of magazines
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: before she bleached her hair or focused her look
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: There was never anything "mousey" about this woman
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: when
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: she changed her hair, her makeup, and her name
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: she didn't become a different person
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: She created an iconic style
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: which she developed in collaboration with her personal makeup artist for many years, Whitey Snyder
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: No doubt Marilyn attended the Max Factor beauty salon near Hollywood Boulevard in the 1940s, along with hundreds of other young starlets
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: I have no reason to disbelieve that she may have worked with Max Factor Jr himself in the 1950s, once she was famous
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: But
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: no one except Marilyn Monroe created Marilyn Monroe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: in 2015 it's past time for us to give credit to the woman who earned it
paragraphs.label: assumption
